Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. *Find sources:* "Jurong Rock Caverns" – news **·** newspapers **·** books **·** scholar **·** JSTOR *(March 2017)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* The **Jurong Rock Caverns** (JRC) ([Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters): 裕廊岛地下储油库, [Malay](/wiki/Malay_language): *Gua Batu Simpanan Barang Mentah Jurong*) is the first underground rock cavern for [oil storage](/wiki/Oil_storage) in [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Southeast_Asia). It is owned by [Jurong Town Corporation](/wiki/Jurong_Town_Corporation). The rock caverns were officially opened on 2 September 2014 by the third [Prime Minister of Singapore](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Singapore), [Lee Hsien Loong](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong). Located at a depth of 130 m (430 ft) beneath Banyan Basin on Jurong Island, the 61-hectare (150-acre) caverns, provide infrastructural support to companies on Jurong Island such as Shell, [ExxonMobil](/wiki/ExxonMobil) and Chevron Philips, and meet the storage needs for liquid hydrocarbons such as crude oil, condensate, naphtha and gas oil. The first phase comprises five 340 m (1,120 ft) long, 20 m (66 ft) wide and 27 m (89 ft) high caverns with nine storage galleries providing 1,470,000 cubic metres (52,000,000 cu ft) of storage, and 8 km (5 mi) of tunnels costing SGD 950 million. The second phase of 1.3 million cubic meter, double this capacity to 2.8 million cubic meters (100 million cu ft). In a study focussed on Swedish policies and conditions in the Cold War (1938-98) it was concluded that environmental investigation into storage of oil and fuel in undressed rock chambers needed to take place over a long period of time, and that the impact and types of potential damage as at 2021 are unknown.
